topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Laura Modi, her Airbnb background, and her founding of Bobbie. He previews themes like momentum, slowing growth strategically, and leadership through tough times.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor reads for Vanta (security compliance) and Element (electrolyte drink mix).

topics.title: Airbnb roles and learning supply-as-product
topics.summary: Laura recaps her Airbnb journey across customer service scaling, European office consolidation, and leading host community/operations. They discuss the marketplace insight that hosts (supply) are the real product and growth follows when you build for them.

topics.title: Culture, energy, and storytelling as leverage
topics.summary: Laura shares key Airbnb lessons: culture as the foundation, energy as organizational currency, and storytelling to align teams and make even small features feel mission-driven. Lenny probes how these ideas translate into concrete practices.

topics.title: From Airbnb to Bobbie: risk and conviction
topics.summary: Laura explains the leap from Airbnb to starting an infant formula company, tying it to a pattern of taking calculated risks (Google→Airbnb, Airbnb→Bobbie). She emphasizes research, financial planning, and conviction over “lucky” career moves.

topics.title: What Bobbie is and why it exists
topics.summary: Laura describes Bobbie as a modern, better-for-you infant formula brand built to remove guilt and stigma. She frames the market as long dominated by a duopoly and out of date with current science and consumer expectations.

topics.title: Formula shortage crisis and choosing to stop growth
topics.summary: During the 2022 formula shortage, Bobbie’s demand surged, but inventory risk threatened existing subscribers. Laura recounts the decision to turn off the site for six months to protect current customers, creating the internal “slowth” mindset and prioritizing trust.

topics.title: Brand building: meet customers where they are
topics.summary: They explore what makes Bobbie’s brand resonate: aligning messaging to the top anxieties parents already have, rather than being loud for its own sake. Laura also explains not trying to “convert” staunch breast-is-best audiences and avoiding competitor finger-pointing.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor read for AssemblyAI (speech-to-text and audio understanding API).

topics.title: Branding internal programs and the FDA setback
topics.summary: Laura explains how naming internal initiatives (like Airbnb’s “Air Dives”) boosts motivation and recall, sharing Bobbie examples like “Secret Shopping.” She then recounts an early FDA labeling issue that forced a product pull and a long compliance “pause,” reinforcing the need for resilience.

topics.title: Managing founder life with three kids
topics.summary: Laura discusses the infrastructure required to balance a fast-growing company with parenting in a dual-founder household. She highlights the importance of support systems (EA, nanny), explicit weekly planning, and treating operations at home like a system.

topics.title: Naivety, hiring generalists, and momentum
topics.summary: Laura argues that “naivety” can unlock innovation in regulated or stagnant industries and shares how she hires for curiosity and speed over narrow credentials. She describes valuing “optimistic doers” who maintain momentum and avoid perfectionism.

topics.title: D2C growth: content and community before commerce
topics.summary: Laura challenges the idea that D2C is dead, arguing the old playbook (over-reliance on paid acquisition) is what’s broken. She outlines Bobbie’s approach—content, community, then commerce—highlighting SEO and the Milk Drunk content platform as long-term growth engines.
